article.title: Arianespace
article.paragraph:
Infobox companyArianespace [[Image:250px-Arianespace logo svg.png|Arianespace Logo]] [[Launch Service Provider]]
1980
[[Courcouronnes]] [[France]]
[[Aerospace]]
{{increase}} [[euro|€]]1.4 billion (2014)<ref name {{increase}} [[euro|€]]3 million (2014)<ref name
321<ref name
[http://www.arianespace.com arianespace.com]
Arianespace SAis a Europeanmultinational companyfounded in 1980 as the world's first commerciallaunch service provider.cite webAriane - The first commercial space transportation systemhttp://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1986spte....2.1431Jadsabs.harvard.edu2008-03-07Dead linkSeptember 2010H3llBotSeated in France, it undertakes the production, operation, and marketing of theAriane 5launch vehicleas part of theAriane (rocket family)Arianeprogramme.cite webArianespace was founded in 1980 as the world’s first launch services and solutions company.http://www.arianespace.com/site/about/arianespace_today_sub_index.htmlarianespace.com2008-03-07http://web.archive.org/web/20080218002917/http://www.arianespace.com/site/about/arianespace_today_sub_index.htmlFebruary 18, 2008Two other launch systems are offered by the company, theSoyuz-2 (rocket)Soyuz-2as a medium-lift alternative to Ariane 5, and theVega (rocket)Vegaas a lighter one.cite webService & Solutionshttp://www.arianespace.com/about-us/service-solutions.asparianespace.com2011-02-15http://web.archive.org/web/20110212040834/http://arianespace.com/about-us/service-solutions.asp12 February 2011no

As of2004, Arianespace held more than 50 percent of the world market for boosting satellites togeostationary transfer orbit(GTO).cite bookThe European UnionJohn McCormick273[[Westview Press]]3978-0-8133-4202-32004More than 240 commercial launches have occurred since May 22, 1984, and Arianespace states that the total number of launch contracts signed since Ariane launches commenced operations in 1984 is 285.Arianespace uses theCentre Spatial GuyanaisinFrench Guianaas a launch site. It has its headquarters inCourcouronnes,Essonne,France,"Russians, French sign space contract.(UPI Science Report)."United Press International. 12 April 2005. Retrieved on 24 September 2009.nearvry, Essonnevry."Contact us." Arianespace. Retrieved on 24 September 2009.

On 21 October 2011 ArianespaceSoyuz at the Guiana Space Centre#Inaugural flightlaunched the first Soyuz rocketever from outside formerSoviet UnionSovietterritory. The payload was twoGalileo (satellite navigation)Galileonavigation satellites.cite webhttp://interspacenews.com/tabid/130/Arianespace_Launches_First_European_Soyuz.aspx?idArianespace Launches First European SoyuzInterspacenews.com2011-12-17
article.heading: The company and its infrastructure
article.paragraph: Arianespace primary shareholders are itsSupply (economics)suppliers, in the various nations of theEuropean Union.cite newsde SeldingPeter B.Europe’s Satellite Operators Urge Swift Development of Ariane 6http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/42610europe%E2%80%99s-satellite-operators-urge-swift-development-of-ariane-62014-11-21SpaceNews2014-11-20''France-based Arianespace has responded by squeezing, to a limited degree, its supplier base. But Ariane 5 builders are also Arianespace shareholders, limiting the company’s leverage on them.''Arianespace currently has 21 shareholders:cite webhttp://www.arianespace.com/about-us-corporate-information/shareholders.aspShareholdersArianespace9 September 2014

Arianespace shareholding is currently being restructured with the creation of an Airbus-Safran joint venture that will develop and manufacture the Ariane 6 launcher. Their subsidiaries shareholdings will be pooled along with the purchase of the French governments CNES stake. Airbus-Safran once the restructure is complete will have a 76% shareholding while the remaining 24% will be spread across ten countries.http://www.satellitetoday.com/launch/2015/06/16/airbus-safran-launchers-gains-cnes-35-percent-stake-in-arianespace/
article.heading: Corporate management

tablerow.tablecell: Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer

article.heading: Offices
Subsidiaries
Competition and pricing
article.paragraph: The disruptive force represented in new sector entrantSpaceX, forced Arianespace to cut workforce, and focus on cost-cutting, to decrease costs to remain competitive against the new low-cost entrant in the launch sector. According to one Arianespace managing director, ""It's quite clear there's a very significant challenge coming fromSpaceX," he said. "Therefore things have to change and the whole European industry is being restructured, consolidated, rationalised and streamlined."cite newshttp://www.smh.com.au/business/nbn-launcher-arianespace-to-cut-jobs-and-costs-to-fight-spacex-20150519-gh4i4x.htmlNBN launcher Arianespace to cut jobs and costs to fight SpaceX19 May 2015David RamliThe Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

In the midst ofcompetition (economics)pricing pressurefrom U.S. companySpaceX, Arianespace made a November 2013 announcement of pricing flexibility for the "lighter satellites" it carries toGeostationary transfer orbitGeostationaryorbits aboard its Ariane 5.cite newsde SeldingPeter B.SpaceX Challenge Has Arianespace Rethinking Pricing Policieshttp://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/38331spacex-challenge-has-arianespace-rethinking-pricing-policies2013-11-27Space News2013-11-25''The Arianespace commercial launch consortium is telling its customers it is open to reducing the cost of flights for lighter satellites on the Ariane 5 rocket in response to the challenge posed by SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket.''In early 2014, Arianespace requested additional subsidies from European governments to face the competition from SpaceX and unfavorable changes in the Euro-Dollar exchange rate.cite newsSvitakAmyArianespace To ESA: We Need Helphttp://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id2014-02-12Aviation Week2014-02-11Reducing pricing allowed Arianespace to sign four additional contracts in September 2014 for a lower slots on an Ariane 5 SYLDA dispenser for the satellites that otherwise could be flown on SpaceX launch vehicle. Overall Arianespace signed 11 contracts in 2014 until September with two additional being in a late stage of negotiations.As of2014SeptemberArianespace has a backlog of launches worthEuro4.5billion with 38 satellites to be launched onAriane 5, 7 onSoyuz at the Guiana Space CentreSoyuzand 9 onVega (rocket)Vega, claiming 60% of global satellite launch market.cite webhttp://spaceflightnow.com/news/n1409/08ariane5contracts/Arianespace nets four commercial launch contracts8 September 20149 September 2014cite press releasehttp://www.arianespace.com/news-press-release/2014/9-8-2014-Euroconsult2014.aspWorld Satellite Business Week 2014: A rich harvest of contracts for Arianespace8 September 20149 September 2014cite webhttp://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2014/09/08/europes-arianespace-claims-60-of-the-commercial-launch-market/Europe's Arianespace Claims 60% Of The Commercial Launch Market9 September 20149 September 2014By November 2014, SpaceX had "already begun to take market share"from Arianespace, andEutelsatCEOMichel de Rosena major customer of Arianespacesaid that "Each year that passes will see SpaceX advance, gain market share and further reduce its costs througheconomies of scale."
article.heading: Launch Vehicles
article.paragraph: Currently Arianespace operates 3 launch vehicles, including two versions of Ariane 5:

link.target: Soyuz at the Guiana Space Centre

article.paragraph: Additionally Arianespace offers optional back-up launch service onH-IIAthroughLaunch Services Alliance.cite webhttp://www.arianespace.com/news-press-release/2013/6-7-2013-MHI.aspMitsubishi Heavy Industries and Arianespace conclude MOU on cooperation in commercial space rocket launchesArianespace7 June 201318 August 2014
article.heading: Ariane launch vehicles
article.paragraph: MainAriane (rocket family)Since the first launch in 1979, there have been several versions of theAriane (rocket)Arianelaunch vehicle:

list.listitem: Ariane 1, first successful launch on December 24, 1979
Ariane 2 and Ariane 3Ariane 2, first successful launch on November 20, 1987(the first launch on May 30, 1986 failed)
Ariane 2 and Ariane 3Ariane 3, first successful launch on August 4, 1984
Ariane 4, first successful launch on June 15, 1988
Ariane 5, first successful launch on October 30, 1997(the first launch on June 4, 1996 failed).
